overview: From 2025-12-01 to 2026-01-01, ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding had 5 new PRs (4 merged), 0 new issues, and 56 active contributors.

topPRs.title: chore(deps): bump urllib3 from 2.5.0 to 2.6.0
topPRs.author: dependabot
topPRs.body:
Bumps [urllib3](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3) from 2.5.0 to 2.6.0.
Release notes

Sourced from urllib3's releases.

2.6.0

ðŸš€ urllib3 is fundraising for HTTP/2 support

urllib3 is raising ~$40,000 USD to release HTTP/2 support and ensure long-term sustainable maintenance of the project after a sharp decline in financial support. If your company or organization uses Python and would benefit from HTTP/2 support in Requests, pip, cloud SDKs, and thousands of other projects please consider contributing financially to ensure HTTP/2 support is developed sustainably and maintained for the long-haul.

Thank you for your support.

Security

  • Fixed a security issue where streaming API could improperly handle highly compressed HTTP content ("decompression bombs") leading to excessive resource consumption even when a small amount of data was requested. Reading small chunks of compressed data is safer and much more efficient now. (CVE-2025-66471 reported by @â€‹Cycloctane, 8.9 High, GHSA-2xpw-w6gg-jr37)
  • Fixed a security issue where an attacker could compose an HTTP response with virtually unlimited links in the Content-Encoding header, potentially leading to a denial of service (DoS) attack by exhausting system resources during decoding. The number of allowed chained encodings is now limited to 5. (CVE-2025-66418 reported by @â€‹illia-v, 8.9 High, GHSA-gm62-xv2j-4w53)

[!IMPORTANT]

  • If urllib3 is not installed with the optional urllib3[brotli] extra, but your environment contains a Brotli/brotlicffi/brotlipy package anyway, make sure to upgrade it to at least Brotli 1.2.0 or brotlicffi 1.2.0.0 to benefit from the security fixes and avoid warnings. Prefer using urllib3[brotli] to install a compatible Brotli package automatically.
  • If you use custom decompressors, please make sure to update them to respect the changed API of urllib3.response.ContentDecoder.

Features

  • Enabled retrieval, deletion, and membership testing in HTTPHeaderDict using bytes keys. (#3653)
  • Added host and port information to string representations of HTTPConnection. (#3666)
  • Added support for Python 3.14 free-threading builds explicitly. (#3696)

Removals

  • Removed the HTTPResponse.getheaders() method in favor of HTTPResponse.headers. Removed the HTTPResponse.getheader(name, default) method in favor of HTTPResponse.headers.get(name, default). (#3622)

Bugfixes

  • Fixed redirect handling in urllib3.PoolManager when an integer is passed for the retries parameter. (#3649)
  • Fixed HTTPConnectionPool when used in Emscripten with no explicit port. (#3664)
  • Fixed handling of SSLKEYLOGFILE with expandable variables. (#3700)

Misc

  • Changed the zstd extra to install backports.zstd instead of zstandard on Python 3.13 and before. (#3693)
  • Improved the performance of content decoding by optimizing BytesQueueBuffer class. (#3710)
  • Allowed building the urllib3 package with newer setuptools-scm v9.x. (#3652)
  • Ensured successful urllib3 builds by setting Hatchling requirement to â‰¥ 1.27.0. (#3638)
Changelog

Sourced from urllib3's changelog.

2.6.0 (2025-12-05)

Security

  • Fixed a security issue where streaming API could improperly handle highly compressed HTTP content ("decompression bombs") leading to excessive resource consumption even when a small amount of data was requested. Reading small chunks of compressed data is safer and much more efficient now. (GHSA-2xpw-w6gg-jr37 <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/security/advisories/GHSA-2xpw-w6gg-jr37>__)
  • Fixed a security issue where an attacker could compose an HTTP response with virtually unlimited links in the Content-Encoding header, potentially leading to a denial of service (DoS) attack by exhausting system resources during decoding. The number of allowed chained encodings is now limited to 5. (GHSA-gm62-xv2j-4w53 <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/security/advisories/GHSA-gm62-xv2j-4w53>__)

.. caution::

  • If urllib3 is not installed with the optional urllib3[brotli] extra, but your environment contains a Brotli/brotlicffi/brotlipy package anyway, make sure to upgrade it to at least Brotli 1.2.0 or brotlicffi 1.2.0.0 to benefit from the security fixes and avoid warnings. Prefer using urllib3[brotli] to install a compatible Brotli package automatically.

  • If you use custom decompressors, please make sure to update them to respect the changed API of urllib3.response.ContentDecoder.

Features

  • Enabled retrieval, deletion, and membership testing in HTTPHeaderDict using bytes keys. ([#3653](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3653) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3653>__)
  • Added host and port information to string representations of HTTPConnection. ([#3666](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3666) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3666>__)
  • Added support for Python 3.14 free-threading builds explicitly. ([#3696](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3696) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3696>__)

Removals

  • Removed the HTTPResponse.getheaders() method in favor of HTTPResponse.headers. Removed the HTTPResponse.getheader(name, default) method in favor of HTTPResponse.headers.get(name, default). ([#3622](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3622) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3622>__)

Bugfixes

  • Fixed redirect handling in urllib3.PoolManager when an integer is passed for the retries parameter. ([#3649](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3649) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3649>__)
  • Fixed HTTPConnectionPool when used in Emscripten with no explicit port. ([#3664](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3664) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3664>__)
  • Fixed handling of SSLKEYLOGFILE with expandable variables. ([#3700](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3700) <https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3700>__)

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 720f484 Release 2.6.0
  • 24d7b67 Merge commit from fork
  • c19571d Merge commit from fork
  • 816fcf0 Bump actions/setup-python from 6.0.0 to 6.1.0 (#3725)
  • 18af0a1 Improve speed of BytesQueueBuffer.get() by using memoryview (#3711)
  • 1f6abac Bump versions of pre-commit hooks (#3716)
  • 1c8fbf7 Bump actions/checkout from 5.0.0 to 6.0.0 (#3722)
  • 7784b9e Add Python 3.15 to CI (#3717)
  • 0241c9e Updated docs to reflect change in optional zstd dependency from zstandard t...
  • 7afcabb Expand environment variable of SSLKEYLOGFILE (#3705)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=urllib3&package-manager=pip&previous-version=2.5.0&new-version=2.6.0)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding/network/alerts).

topContributors.summary: sbvegan: Focused on improving the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, merging four pull requests this month. Their most impactful contribution was a large-scale refactor to fix documentation formatting in PR #1901, which involved over 3,000 lines of changes. They also improved site integrity by fixing redirects (#1907) and enhanced discoverability by adding SEO metadata (#1904). In addition to their own work, they supported the team by providing five code reviews, with their efforts primarily concentrated on documentation files.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on developing new functionality for OPCM V2 and providing extensive code review support for the team. They authored a significant pull request to modify Solidity scripts with branching logic (`ethereum-optimism/optimism#18458`), which included over 750 lines of new code. While this feature work is still in progress, they were highly engaged in collaboration, providing 30 code reviews. Their contributions indicate a focus on a mix of feature work, bugfixes, and tests.

smartcontracts: Focused on developing the OPCMv2 feature within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, making a significant contribution by refactoring utilities into helper contracts in a large PR (#18454, +2034/-514 lines). They ensured the quality of this new functionality by adding comprehensive deployment tests in PR #18486 and actively supported teammates by conducting 18 code reviews. This work was part of a broader effort that included several open PRs to enhance OPCMv2 and was characterized by a primary focus on bug fixes and extensive testing to support new feature delivery.

geoknee: Focused on broad project contributions, merging several small pull requests for tweaks and documentation clarifications like in `optimism#18480` and `docs#1902`. They were highly active in collaboration, providing 19 code reviews, and helped plan future work by opening key issues for a new `op-spammer` component (`optimism#18482`) and expanded test coverage (`optimism#18515`). Underlying this activity were substantial code modifications totaling over 86k added lines across 1752 files. This work was primarily focused on tests and other general code improvements.

Inphi: Inphi focused on improving the fault proof system's test coverage and planning for future superchain capabilities. They enhanced the system's correctness by merging a pull request to add end-to-end tests for delegatecalled precompiles (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18475). Inphi also demonstrated significant forward-thinking by creating 13 issues to scope upcoming work on kona-sp1, supernode APIs, and contract interactions, while actively supporting the team through 14 code reviews.

serpixel: Focused on enhancing deployment and infrastructure tooling this month, merging two key feature PRs. They implemented significant new capabilities in `op-acceptor`, adding multigate and dry-run functionality via `ethereum-optimism/infra#520` (+577/-81 lines). Additionally, they improved the artifact publishing process by modifying the `op-deployer` build in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18488`. Alongside this development work, which was split evenly between features and bugfixes, serpixel was an active collaborator, providing 12 code reviews.

falcorocks: Made significant improvements to CI infrastructure across multiple repositories, merging 8 PRs to enhance security and reliability. Their most impactful contribution was optimism#18501, which reduced permissions for fork builds and fixed tag releases (+399/-307 lines). They also refactored CI workflows by splitting runs between protected and unprotected branches in infra#519 and unifying local workflows in ecosystem#971. This activity shows a primary focus on bug fixes and other enhancements within configuration files.
almanax-ai: No activity this month.

ajsutton: This month, ajsutton led the effort to add ZK fault proof support to the `op-challenger` service in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They merged a series of impactful pull requests to introduce core functionality, including the ability to challenge invalid ZK games (#18442), resolve optimistic games (#18464), and reclaim bonds (#18465). This implementation work, which was preceded by their own planning and spike issues (#18322, #18321), was substantial, with several PRs adding over 500 lines of new code and tests. Alongside this focused development, they also supported the team by providing 12 code reviews.

janjakubnanista focused on bug fixes within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository this month. Their main contribution was merging a fix to resolve a build issue related to the FFI build process (PR #18527). In addition to this merged work, they have two open pull requests for a cache bump and an error handling improvement, and also provided one review approval. Their work touched configuration, code, and test files, indicating a focus on system stability and maintenance.

scharissis: Focused on improving the acceptance testing infrastructure, delivering a key fix and refactor in `ethereum-optimism/infra#525` (+512/-177 lines) to streamline log handling in the `op-acceptor`. They also performed related maintenance, updating test versions and cleaning up old logs in the `optimism` repository (`#18530`, `#18529`). This work reflects a primary focus on tests and bugfixes.

teddyknox: Focused on significant feature work and refactoring within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository this month. They landed a substantial PR (#18453) to add kona-healthcheck support to the conductor, which involved a significant implementation of over 2,300 new lines of code. In addition to providing 9 code reviews, they have also begun a major refactoring effort in a work-in-progress PR (#18504). Teddyknox's work primarily focused on application logic and tests.

JosepBove: This month, JosepBove focused on expanding and stabilizing the Superchain's CI and deployment infrastructure, merging 6 pull requests. Their most impactful contribution was adding the Openchain import on CI in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18447`, a massive change that added over 75k lines. In addition to shipping features like a new deployment script (`ethereum-optimism/optimism#18448`) and fixing CI (`ethereum-optimism/optimism#18450`), they also supported the team by providing 9 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on documentation and configuration files across the ecosystem.

pcw109550: Focused on developing the Light Consensus Layer (CL) feature within the `op-node` for the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They authored two significant open pull requests (#18500, #18514) to implement this functionality, contributing over 2000 lines of new code across 117 files. In addition to this development work, they created a related issue (#18316) and were an active participant in code review, providing 13 reviews and several comments.

theochap: This month, theochap's activity was focused on documentation maintenance. They merged one pull request in `ethereum-optimism/docs` (#1896) to update version numbers. This work was focused entirely within documentation files.

ccerv1: Focused on updating data for the Retro-Funding program this month, merging four pull requests. Their most significant contribution was adding the draft results for M10 in PR #86, a substantial update that added over 51,000 lines. They also made several adjustments to the program's weights for onchain builders (PR #87, #88), with their work primarily involving modifications to configuration files.

0xDiscotech: This month, 0xDiscotech focused on contract maintenance within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, merging a significant chore PR (#18490) to update the fees depositor address and minimum withdrawal amount, which involved over 7,000 lines of changes. This work appears related to an issue they created (#17505) and is complemented by an open proposal for new L2 fee splitter contracts (#18474). They also actively engaged in collaboration, providing 5 reviews and 4 PR comments. Their code changes indicate a primary focus on bug fixes and other maintenance, touching code, tests, and configuration files.

karlfloersch: Focused on initiating a new service, opening a pull request for an `op-interop-filter` service skeleton in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#18456). While this work remains in progress, they also actively supported the team by providing 10 code reviews.

pauldowman: Focused on planning and configuration work for the challenger and Kona components within the Optimism ecosystem. They created seven issues in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (e.g., #18427, #18415) to scope out required work for the challenger service. Additionally, pauldowman merged a configuration update to add Kona prestates in `ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry#1174` and opened a PR to add tests for a precompile limit in `ethereum-optimism/op-geth#731`. Their contributions this month were primarily focused on tests and other related work.

Their work includes preparing an "Upgrade 18 Template" (superchain-ops#1313) and updating task nonces for Soneium Sepolia (superchain-ops#1316). These changes represent a significant effort, with over 1900 lines of code added across 62 files, the majority of which (67%) were test files.

Their work was concentrated on feature development and tests, primarily modifying test and configuration files.

agusduha: Made a significant number of local code changes this month across 9 commits, modifying 394 files (+13734/-5489 lines). While no pull requests were merged, they participated in collaboration by providing 2 reviews and 3 comments on others' work. This activity indicates a primary focus on bug fixes, alongside contributions to new features and tests.

This in-progress effort is extensive, reflected in over 7,000 lines of code added and 2,700 removed across 207 files. In addition to this development, they supported the team by approving 3 pull requests and opened an issue to track further test development (#18461). This work demonstrates a primary focus on bugfixes and configuration.
